figure.label: Peña de los EnamoradosLovers' Rock near.
The Moor had a Castle on the top. Peña de los Enamorados Lovers' Rock near.
Story of the Moor against whose caslte the Queen came by a miraculous road. He leaped down.

div.ab: The Venta de ArchidoneCountry inn at Archidona rather a good house. bill 5 dollars all but 2 shillings – quit it at 12h. L Left a large town called ArchidoneArchidona with a ruined castle. The plain Arcadian that is the mts mountains rise at once from the flat. Robbers said to be deserters in the country one taken up at the corner of our ventacountry inn this morning. In about an hour, at the end of the plain ascend from it leaving the Peña de los EnamoradosLovers' Rock L & the river of the valley left again of it. Story of an inhabt of Antequera running away with his mistress faster than the Justice could pursue on horseback. They threw themselves at length from the top. the rock really overhangs. A fine view at the top of the vale of Antequera very large, & the town of Antequera. the VegaFertile Plain very flat several trees. rich in corn. Abt 2h X About 2pm cross the river from Archidone. at 3h 40m3.40pm Antequera. in the way stones ancient Roman mark the road in the plain. Antiquera Anticaria large.
div.note: + quan admirablemente ha dispensado su rigor y clemencia con los que debe; entendiendo que en dispensar sus tesoros en esto era la posesion que de ellos hascia. Perpetuamente quede sublimado en alteza; a la qual todos los Reyes se humillen e teman el furor de la execution de su shoulder espadla espalda ansi los naturales Moros, como los de otra qualquiera nacion.” From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, pp. 13-14. [It is he who provokes admiration among Kings for the purity of his birth, and he whom the great imitate, seeing...] how admirably he has granted his rigour and his clemency to those to whom he owes it [hascia=hacía]; understanding that the possession of his treasures lay in granting them. He remains perpetually sublimated in highness; before which all Kings humble themselves and fear the use [AA has 'execucion'] of his sword, native Moors like those of any other nation. AA has 'espada' (sword), but WG has confused this with 'espalda' (back or sometimes shoulder), which he has itself corrected from 'espadla'.Another

“Soy estrado carpet de esposo de linda hermosura y cumplimiento. Y si quieres ver la razon de lo que digo mirad la hermosura desde mi caliz e avertid en mi corona y tiara; y vereis como es semejante a la de la luna. Y Aben Nasëre es el Sol de mi orbe, de rutilante hermosura e ser resplandor, luce en alteza de estado, seguro de toda ausencia y apartamiento” From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 14. I am a husband's carpeted room of beautiful loveliness and accomplishment. And if you want to see the truth of what I say, look at the beauty of this [AA has 'deste'] my chalice, and notice [AA has 'advertid'] [the beauty] of my crown and tiara, and you will see how alike it is to that of the moon. And Aben Nasere is the sun of my world, of glittering beauty and radiance [AA has no 'ser']: he shines in highness of status, safe from all want and isolation. Another

ornament Soy decoration aseo de magnificencia señal y hechura que sobrepuja surpasses a la felicidad: entendereis ser en este mi atavio ornament, este precioso caliz, alguno que esta en pie cumpliendo su oracion. Y todo lo que de el se vacia conviene que luego se le reitere; e con mi Señor Aben Nasere ennoblecio dios sus criaturas que procede del senor Alhazragi Zahade Aben Obeda.From Antigüedades árabes, vol. 2, p. 14. I am a washroom of magnificence, a sign and a work that surpasses happiness: you will understand that in this my attire, this precious chalice, is one who is on his feet fulfilling his prayer. And all that is drained from it should later be replaced; and with my Lord Aben Nasere, God ennobled his creatures, who [Aben Nasere] proceeds from Lord Alhazragi Zahde [according to AA] Aben Obeda. WG has corrected an apparent printing error in Antigüedades árabes, which gives 'rodo lo que...' rather than 'todo'.
